War's rapid havock roll'd along,</br>Impell'd by Valour's ardent flame;</br>She led the death-denouncing throng,</br>Daughter of EUDAF, glorious name!</br>Her breast more white than driven snow,—</br>That breast receives the deadly blow;</br>Well-aim'd the Saxon flung his dart:</br>The peerless BRADWEN breathes no more;</br>Behold her bosom drench'd in gore!</br>The last warm drop forsakes her heart.</br>Madden'd, we view the rage-inspiring sight,</br>Her eyes untimely clos'd in Death's eternal night.

Fair leader of th' undaunted host,</br>Of all the warrior's worth possest,</br>In youth's high bloom for ever lost,</br>With tears we drench thy lovely breast!</br>Whilst stamping wild we tear the ground,</br>And bid the trump of Slaughter sound.</br>The briny streams of Anguish flow,</br>Thy bands by deep resentment fir'd,</br>By fierce indignant rage inspir'd,</br>Hurl vengeance on thy ruthless foe.—</br>Soon shall th' avenging lance, th' unerring dart,</br>In search of sweet revenge pervade that Saxon's heart.

Soon shall thy legion's dreadful ire</br>Shower on thy foes the hail of Death,</br>Fierce as the storm-excited fire,</br>That desolates the blazing heath.</br>Lost in Distraction's wild amaze,</br>We on thy blood-stain'd beauty gaze;</br>Whilst thy great soul ascends the sky.</br>True to thy worth, we grasp the lance,</br>Bid Slaughter's hurried powers advance,</br>And in thy death their thousands die:</br>They fall!  they load th' obstructed fields of War,</br>Where Triumph mounts for thee the blood-bespangled car.

Tuesday, that sad, that woeful day,</br>Gave BRADWEN to the trophy'd urn:</br>In sable robe, dumb Grief's array,</br>Thrice lovely fair, thy heroes mourn.</br>Long shall the glories of thy name</br>Stand foremost on the rolls of fame,</br>The Bard's high strain for ever grace.—</br>This view relieves each aching breast;</br>We, with this chearing thought impress'd,</br>Kiss thy dead lips, our last embrace.—</br>Till Time expires, thro' distant ages far,</br>Thy tale shall rouse to life th' avenging soul of War.

Wednesday's clear dawn illum'd the skies;</br>Their task the sons of Death resume:</br>Britons!  dead BRADWEN calls!  arise!</br>Revenge!  revenge her hapless doom!</br>The gore-dash'd mead's inflaming horn</br>Employ'd black Thursday's deathful morn;</br>Loud rang the warrior's wonted lay,</br>Now rushing wild on carnage bent,</br>Ere noon proclaims the dire event,</br>Destruction's fury marks their way;</br>The Saxons fall!  we view their mingled blood</br>Stream down the crimson'd brink, and swell the foamy flood.

Nature compell'd, we sought repose;</br>Sleep chain'd us to th' unfeeling dead;</br>'Till Friday's frighten'd morn arose,</br>And rous'd us from the bloody bed:</br>O'er Cattraeth's field we wander far,</br>Explore the gory track of war,</br>In search of our much honour'd slain.</br>Lost in th' astonishment of life,</br>We view the dreadful scene of strife,</br>The slaughter'd legions heap the plain;</br>Sole monarch of the blood-enamel'd place,</br>Exulting Horror shews his heart-benumbing face.

Saturday's peaceful morn appears;</br>No battle treads the mangled ground;</br>Afar no weeping mother hears</br>Of clashing steel the dreadful sound.</br>Sunday we grasp the blade again,</br>Death stalks a giant o'er the plain,</br>Hurries huge havock far and wide.</br>Thro' dreadful Monday's heart-sprung flood</br>The battle wades, thro' Saxon blood</br>Augmenting still the purple tide.</br>Abhorring Nature, struck with wild affright,</br>Flies from the reeking field, and shudders at the sight.

At Madoc's tent the clarion sounds,</br>With rending clangor hurry'd far:</br>From Echo's caves each note rebounds;</br>But when return the Sons of War?</br>Thou, sprung from dire Necessity,</br>Dumb Peace, the desart yields to thee,</br>Owns now thy melancholy sway.</br>Loud sounds the trump, and loud again:</br>What trump can wake th' unheeding slain?</br>What call revive the breathless clay?</br>One, only one, hears the continued blast,</br>And, bleeding, crawls along the slaughter-mantled waste.

One tent contains our living few,</br>Each by the fangs of battle torn;</br>Unchear'd we taste, with pain we view,</br>Sad Victory's replenish'd horn.</br>See, traversing the track of Death,</br>With wilder'd look, with panting breath,</br>Yon throng possest of wretched life!</br>What doleful moans, what woeful cries,</br>Of weeping mothers rend the skies,</br>Of orphan'd babe, and widow'd wife,</br>Shrieking aghast!  they view the trampled host,</br>Where all their joys expir'd, where all their hopes are lost.

Struck dumb with grief, yon drooping Fair</br>Over her clay-cold lover weeps:</br>Sweet Nymph, thy sighs are spent in air,</br>On Death's eternal bed he sleeps:</br>He wakes no more to glad thy sight,</br>Thy charms can him no more delight:</br>In his loved arms no longer prest,</br>Thy hopes are all forever fled,</br>Joyless reclines th' unconscious head</br>On that once dear, that lovely breast;</br>Yet sympathetic Pity feels thy grief,</br>Can mingle tears with thine; but what can yield relief!</br>
